title: ‘When It Was My Turn to Order, the Vendor Handed Me His Fork’
description: Kebabs on the grill, a somber sight on the way to the work and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make Dorie Greenspan’s latest, an elegant icebox cake, or a comforting alphabet soup.
content: Good morning. How are you doing? I know it’s not easy, not if you’re flying solo, not if you’re crammed into a too-small apartment with two dogs and a baby, not if you’re on a saltwater farm 17 miles from town with grandchildren romping in the soft spring grass. It’s not easy if you’re not working. It’s not easy if you’re working or going to school, either. It’s not easy for any of us. The future’s still out there, mirage-like in the distance. Sometimes it looks promising — as if summer could bring normalcy, a haircut, a trip to the crowded farmers’ market, a swim at the beach, at the pond, at the rec-center pool in town. But it’s often the opposite. Fear’s like that: awful and menacing. There’s so much we don’t know, can’t know, can’t imagine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Group That Meets on the Slopes
description: Have a seat and take a crack at Ross Trudeau’s Monday puzzle.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Looking at the current weather, I feel like half of you will see the photo above and want to storm the snow fort that I almost managed to build, yesterday, in New York. Hopefully the murder hornets all turned stinger and flew south!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Teenager, an Aspiring Detective, Returns $135,000 He Found
description: Jose Nuñez Romaniz, a criminal justice student, turned over the money to officials and was invited to apply for an entry-level job at the Albuquerque Police Department.
content: Jose Nuñez Romaniz was headed to the bank to deposit money so he could buy socks online for his grandfather when he came upon a large clear plastic bag filled with cash next to an A.T.M. in Albuquerque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Has Trump Decided We Will Follow Sweden and Just Not Told Us?
description: The president brings instability and confusion to a crisis.
content: Having a pandemic is really bad. Having a pandemic and a civil war together is really, really bad. Welcome to Donald Trump’s America 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary B. McCord
title: Bill Barr Twisted My Words in Dropping the Flynn Case. Here’s the Truth.
description: The F.B.I.’s interview of Mr. Flynn was constitutional, lawful and for a legitimate counterintelligence purpose.
content: At the direction of Attorney General Bill Barr, the Justice Department last week moved to dismiss a false-statements charge against Michael Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser. The reason stated was that the continued prosecution “would not serve the interests of justice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: After 4 Years of Silence, a Call to Mom on Mother’s Day
description: A son’s attempt at mending a rift.
content: Call, I demanded of myself. Call her now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Iran Seeks Unconditional Talks on Prisoner Swap
description: Warning that Iranians are at risk of Covid-19 while held in the United States, officials in Tehran say there is a “readiness for all prisoners” to be discussed.
content: Iran says it is ready for unconditional talks with the United States on a prisoner swap because of fears that the coronavirus is endangering inmates, the Iranian news media reported Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: Daniel Dae Kim on ‘Asian-Americans’: Ugly History, Relevant Again
description: Kim, who narrates the PBS documentary, discusses its unanticipated resonance in the age of Covid-19 and his own experiences with the disease.
content: In late March, the actor Daniel Dae Kim posted a video on Instagram revealing that he had tested positive for Covid-19. Back then Kim, best known for memorable roles on “Lost” and “Hawaii Five-0,” was one of the early well-known carriers of the coronavirus, having potentially contracted it while filming his NBC medical drama “New Amsterdam” in New York City. He documented his recovery process online while most Americans were just beginning to comprehend the impact of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Self-Interest and Profiteering During a Pandemic
description: Instead of promoting the public welfare, some people are using this crisis to profit or to push their agendas, readers write. Also: Health insurers’ response.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: Daniel Dae Kim on ‘Asian-Americans’: Ugly History, Relevant Again
description: Kim, who narrates the PBS documentary, discusses its unanticipated resonance in the age of Covid-19 and his own experiences with the disease.
content: In late March, the actor Daniel Dae Kim posted a video on Instagram revealing that he had tested positive for Covid-19. Back then Kim, best known for memorable roles on “Lost” and “Hawaii Five-0,” was one of the early well-known carriers of the coronavirus, having potentially contracted it while filming his NBC medical drama “New Amsterdam” in New York City. He documented his recovery process online while most Americans were just beginning to comprehend the impact of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Self-Interest and Profiteering During a Pandemic
description: Instead of promoting the public welfare, some people are using this crisis to profit or to push their agendas, readers write. Also: Health insurers’ response.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Corkery
title: Pork Chops vs. People: Battling Coronavirus in an Iowa Meat Plant
description: After President Trump’s executive order, meat plants are reopening. Can they do so without endangering their low-wage workers and their communities?
content: On April 10, Tony Thompson, the sheriff for Black Hawk County in Iowa, visited the giant Tyson Foods pork plant in Waterloo. What he saw, he said, “shook me to the core.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Carpenter
title: Not Quite a Car, Not Quite a Motorcycle: A Vehicle Built for One
description: From the front, the Solo looks like a car, with hood, grille and headlights. Take a peek from behind, however, and it tapers down to just one wheel.
content: For decades, the country’s best-selling vehicles have been pickup trucks. Hulking, gas-powered models from Ford, Ram and Chevy have had a grip on the market that seems unbreakable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman
title: ‘Scary to Go to Work’: White House Races to Contain Virus in Its Ranks
description: With two White House staff members testing positive, some officials fear the disease is already spreading rapidly through the West Wing.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is racing to contain an outbreak of the coronavirus inside the White House, as some senior officials believe that the disease is already spreading rapidly through the warren of cramped offices that make up the three floors of the West Wing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Keeping Online Testing Honest? Or an Orwellian Overreach?
description: The rise of proctoring software to deter cheating alarms privacy advocates. Some students and professors find it invasive, too.
content: SACRAMENTO — As Daniel Farzannekou prepared to take an online exam late last month in his naval science elective at the University of California, Los Angeles, the software directed him to pick up his laptop and scan his room, his desk, his ID and his face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
title: U.S. to Accuse China of Trying to Hack Vaccine Data, as Virus Redirects Cyberattacks
description: Iran and other nations are also looking to steal data and exploit the pandemic with attacks on infrastructure, officials say.
content: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. and the Department of Homeland Security are preparing to issue a warning that China’s most skilled hackers and spies are working to steal American research in the crash effort to develop vaccines and treatments for the coronavirus. The efforts are part of a surge in cybertheft and attacks by nations seeking advantage in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Boris Johnson Announces a Coronavirus Quarantine for Travelers to U.K.: Live Coverage
description: Coronavirus cases soar past 4 million as China finds a new cluster near Russia. Ethiopian troops may have shot down an aid plane in Somalia.
content: Worldwide, the officially reported number of coronavirus cases has soared above four million people across 177 countries, and more than a quarter million people have died, according to a New York Times database.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Michael Rothfeld
title: Why the Path to Reopening New York City Will Be So Difficult
description: The factors that made the city one of the hardest hit on the planet — its density, mass transit and tourism — complicate a return to normalcy.
content: Nearly 190,000 people were tested for the coronavirus in New York City over the past two weeks, a record number. The increase in testing, crucial for curbing the outbreak, came as Mayor Bill de Blasio announced plans to hire a small army of 1,000 disease detectives to track down the contacts of every infected New Yorker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: How Pandemics End
description: An infectious outbreak can conclude in more ways than one, historians say. But for whom does it end, and who gets to decide?
content: When will the Covid-19 pandemic end? And how?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: As Europe Reopens Schools, Relief Combines With Risk
description: Restarting classes is central to reviving economies. But one question haunts the efforts: Just how contagious are children, and could they be the next super spreaders?
content: NEUSTRELITZ, Germany — It was Lea Hammermeister’s first day back at school after almost two months at home and she was already preparing for a test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Lebanon’s Economic Crisis Explodes, Threatening Decades of Prosperity
description: Bad planning, corruption and the sudden shock of a pandemic have caused the Lebanese currency to crash and consumer prices to jump. Hunger looms.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Flawed policies and sudden shocks have thrust Lebanon into its worst economic crisis in decades, with its currency collapsing, businesses shutting, prices for basic goods skyrocketing and the threat of hunger looming for its poorest people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Surviving Covid-19 May Not Feel Like Recovery for Some
description: Debilitating symptoms can last long after a person’s body has gotten rid of the coronavirus, a reality Italians are now confronting.
content: ROME — When Morena Colombi tested negative for the coronavirus on March 16, the official tallies counted her among the Covid-19 recoveries, a success amid the tragedies overwhelming Italy. But she was nowhere near recovered, her cough and crippling fatigue nowhere near gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack and Sheri Fink
title: Franklin Graham Is Taking Down His N.Y. Hospital, but Not Going Quietly
description: His critics accuse him of discriminating against L.G.B.T. people. “Just because I don’t agree doesn’t mean I’m against them,” he said.
content: The last patients have been discharged from the Central Park field hospital run by Samaritan’s Purse, the evangelical organization led by the Rev. Franklin Graham. Its white tents will soon be dismantled and sent to new makeshift coronavirus wards as far away as Ecuador and Alaska.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Will the Pandemic End? And How?
description: The infection has now penetrated the White House, where two aides have tested positive. Unemployment could climb above 20 percent. And states are grappling with when and how to reopen.
content: When will the Covid-19 pandemic end? And how?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Shark Attack Kills Surfer in Northern California
description: Ben Kelly, 26, who designed boards for a living, was surfing at Manresa State Beach near Santa Cruz when he was attacked.
content: A man was killed in a shark attack as he was surfing at a state beach in Northern California on Saturday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Victoria Hammarskjold, George Lemmon III
description: The couple met and began dating as high-school students.
content: Victoria Frances Hammarskjold and George Blackmore Lemmon III were married May 9. The couple self-united, as allowed by Pennsylvania law, at their home in Devon, Pa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Salutes Mothers as Baldwin’s Trump Gives Advice to Graduates
description: Tina Fey joined the Mother’s Day tribute in the remotely-produced season finale, which also featured Kristen Wiig and Boyz II Men.
content: A “Saturday Night Live” season that was more abrupt than intended and still more generous than it had to be came to a bittersweet end this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lorraine Duffy Merkl
title: Let the Pandemic Apologies Begin
description: Those of us who’ve always lived the coronavirus life are ready to forgive you.
content: Before we were all nudged, advised and ordered to repeatedly wash our hands, wear face masks, stay home and social distance, some of us did so by choice. You know who we are, the ones you mocked, at whom you rolled your eyes, and for whom you made up nicknames.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: The Trump Administration Is Made of Swiss Cheese
description: All the holes and temps in the government have led to a permanent crisis.
content: This we already know: The president has contempt for expertise. During a national emergency, President Trump’s top economic adviser is a former television host; his supply-chain coordinator is his son-in-law, who majored in nepotism and prioritizes the leads and needs of cronies; the chief of staff at his Department of Health and Human Services is a former breeder of Australian labradoodles, an insolently unqualified choice if there ever was one, though at least the man is well versed in the behaviors of lapdogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: Betty Wright, Soul Singer Who Mentored a New Generation, Dies at 66
description: She had her first hit, “Clean Up Woman,” when she was only 17 and became a key player in the Miami funk sound of the 1970s.
content: Betty Wright, a powerful singer who had a breakout hit single when she was 17, then went on to be a key player in the Miami funk sound of the 1970s, and worked closely with singers and rappers in the following four decades, died on Sunday at her home in Miami. She was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chatting via Zoom: A Blessing or a Blight?
description: For one reader, Zoom is “the difference being sentenced to solitary confinement or to just being part of the Covid-19 general prison population.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘I Know This Much Is True’ and ‘Call Your Mother’
description: Mark Ruffalo stars alongside himself in a new HBO limited series, and Comedy Central introduces us to the mothers who raised famous comedians.
content: I KNOW THIS MUCH IS TRUE 9 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. This limited series, based on Wally Lamb’s 1998 novel, stars Mark Ruffalo as the twins Dominick and Thomas Birdsey. Written and directed by Derek Cianfrance (“Blue Valentine,” “The Place Beyond the Pines”), the six-episode series follows Dominick as he tries to care for his brother, who has schizophrenia, and who cuts off his right hand in the opening scene of the book. To embody two distinctly different identical twins, Ruffalo told The New York Times that he gained 30 pounds during a six-week filming break before shooting his scenes as Thomas. As the twins deal with familial trauma and mental illness, they grapple with the messy nature of care and conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Sunday Read’: The Iceman in Winter
description: What happened to Val Kilmer? The unlikeliest star in Hollywood history is just starting to figure it out.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 11, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Concert to Test Whether America Is Ready to Rock Again
description: Travis McCready is set to perform in Arkansas on Friday in what appears to be the first major U.S. music show since the pandemic began, but state officials have yet to endorse it.
content: Being first is often a good thing, but the opening this week of what could be the first major concert in the United States is turning into a fraught affair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: The Airline Business Is Terrible. It Will Probably Get Even Worse.
description: An industry that is intimately familiar with failure confronts a crisis unlike any other. Executives say they have no idea when passengers will return.
content: Delta Air Lines started 2020 celebrating what it said was the most successful year in company history. Not long after, it shared a record $1.6 billion in profits with its 90,000 employees. But with air travel nearly shut down by the coronavirus, the airline is now bleeding money and will drop 10 more airports from its already skeletal network on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi and Ryan Christopher Jones
title: Paramedics, Strained in the Hot Zone, Pull Back From CPR
description: Their mission is to save lives at any cost. But in New Jersey, the coronavirus has sickened so many emergency workers that some units are holding off on risky procedures like CPR.
content: NEWARK — The calls for patients in cardiac arrest came in one after another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: New York City ‘Can’t Afford to Get This Wrong’
description: Mayor de Blasio should let the health department do its Covid-19 tracing.
content: Much is uncertain about New York City’s future amid coronavirus — the timeline for reopening, the timeline for development of treatments and a vaccine. But one thing has remained clear: In order to safely reopen, cities like New York must develop the capacity to regularly test portions of the population, trace the spread of the virus and isolate those who have been exposed. And as the count of those struggling both in health and finances continues to mount, time is of the essence. New York needs contact tracing quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Britain to Impose Quarantine on Air Travelers to Fight Coronavirus
description: “Stay alert,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned as the government eased restrictions on movement.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Sunday that Britain would soon impose a mandatory quarantine on travelers arriving in the country by air to try to avert a new wave of coronavirus infections, signaling how cautious the country will be in relaxing its seven-week lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Britain to Impose Quarantine on Air Travelers to Fight Coronavirus
description: “Stay alert,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned as the government eased restrictions on movement.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Sunday that Britain would soon impose a mandatory quarantine on travelers arriving in the country by air to try to avert a new wave of coronavirus infections, signaling how cautious the country will be in relaxing its seven-week lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Ethiopian Troops May Have Shot Down Aid Plane in Somalia, Report Says
description: The Kenyan-registered aircraft was delivering much-needed humanitarian supplies for the fight against the coronavirus when it crashed.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — A plane carrying humanitarian supplies that crashed in Somalia on Monday may have been shot down by Ethiopian troops, according to a new report from the office of the African Union Force Commander in Somalia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 10, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 10, 2020.
content: A capsule summary of an article on Saturday about prosecutors’ concerns over Attorney General William P. Barr’s handling of the criminal case against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn misstated the action taken by Mr. Barr. The attorney general dropped the case; Mr. Flynn was not pardoned.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Deep Yearning for Hometown Lost to a Virus
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 10, 2020.
content: “Just everything. I miss everything.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: It’s Ugly Out There
description: The April jobs report showed unemployment numbers that rival the Great Depression.
content: Happy weirdest Mother’s Day ever to all the moms out there, especially mine, whom I’m not sure when I’ll see next (besides on Zoom, of course). To everyone else, hang in there. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech for the week ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Amanda Mustard
title: Bangkok Opens Up as Virus Caseloads Drop, and Pretty Pups Benefit
description: Bangkok is crazy for purebred dogs. Some wear nail polish, and many wear clothes. Our overheated schnauzer needed a trim, and the government opened up pet groomers just in time.
content: BANGKOK — When the coronavirus lockdown in Bangkok eased a bit after six weeks, the first appointment my family made was not for a medical checkup or a walk in a park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Penn Bullock and Elijah Walker
title: Reopening Risks, Ahmaud Arbery, Mother’s Day: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Esplin Odell and Stephen Wertheim
title: Can the Democrats Avoid Trump’s China Trap?
description: The president wants a new cold war to deflect attention from his failures.
content: Before the pandemic, before the Great Recession, before proliferating hurricanes and fires, the United States began a global war on terrorism. Its leaders fixated on a shadowy enemy abroad as life at home crumbled for millions of Americans. The war on terrorism did not end terrorism; the war itself became endless. What it did shatter was the myth that a triumphant United States could bend the world to its will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Democrats’ Vote-by-Mail Effort Won in Wisconsin: Will It Work Elsewhere?
description: After winning by a surprising margin in a key Wisconsin judicial race, Democrats are hoping they can replicate the same game plan.
content: It was a shocking margin of victory in what was expected to be a close race: an 11-point blowout by a liberal judge over a conservative incumbent for a seat on the Wisconsin Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Aimee Ortiz
title: Ex-Deputy Charged After Armed White ‘Mob’ Confronts Black Family
description: The deputy was fired after “terrorizing” a North Carolina family in what appeared to be a case of mistaken identity, officials said.
content: A former sheriff’s deputy faces charges after “terrorizing” a black family in North Carolina as part of a large group of white men and women, some of whom were armed, in what appeared to be a case of mistaken identity, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Comfort Viewing: 3 Reasons I Love ‘Little House on the Prairie’
description: Don’t judge: The series is a reassuring balance between sweet and sour, and can be transporting to a more carefree time.
content: LOS ANGELES — About 15 years ago, I stopped by the old Tower Records on the Sunset Strip in West Hollywood. I browsed the CD area. Meh. But I did find a DVD that I couldn’t live without, and I brought it to the register, where a trendier-than-thou clerk suddenly appeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: From Coffee Filter to Safety Mask, in a Hurry
description: Melitta, the German maker of the original paper coffee filter, retooled its production to make masks. A director called the filter’s perfect fit over the face “a gift from heaven.”
content: BERLIN — As the wave of coronavirus infections broke over Europe in March, causing reserves of medical supplies to disappear, German authorities made a nationwide appeal: More safety masks were urgently needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Democrats’ Vote-by-Mail Effort Won in Wisconsin: Will It Work Elsewhere?
description: After winning by a surprising margin in a key Wisconsin judicial race, Democrats are hoping they can replicate the same game plan.
content: It was a shocking margin of victory in what was expected to be a close race: an 11-point blowout by a liberal judge over a conservative incumbent for a seat on the Wisconsin Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Aimee Ortiz
title: Ex-Deputy Charged After Armed White ‘Mob’ Confronts Black Family
description: The deputy was fired after “terrorizing” a North Carolina family in what appeared to be a case of mistaken identity, officials said.
content: A former sheriff’s deputy faces charges after “terrorizing” a black family in North Carolina as part of a large group of white men and women, some of whom were armed, in what appeared to be a case of mistaken identity, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Audra D. S. Burch
title: Questions of Bias in Covid-19 Treatment Add to the Mourning for Black Families
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have advised health professionals to be on the lookout for medical bias.
content: Long dissatisfied with the doctor treating his diabetes, Reginald Relf decided to fight through whatever was causing his nagging cough. But then his temperature spiked and his breathing became so labored that he reluctantly took his sister’s advice to visit a doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Skadden Said to Have Paid $11 Million to Settle Ukraine Dispute
description: The law firm paid a former Ukrainian prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, and an associate to avert a suit over its role in a report justifying her imprisonment by a political rival.
content: WASHINGTON — The New York-based law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom has paid $11 million or more to avoid a lawsuit by a former Ukrainian prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, who blamed the firm for aiding in her political persecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: In U.K., Hard-Hit Minority Communities Struggle to Bury the Dead
description: The coronavirus outbreak has disproportionately affected some areas of Britain. A Birmingham mosque’s car park has been transformed into a makeshift mortuary to handle the influx of bodies.
content: BIRMINGHAM, England — Normally, the mosque, one of England’s largest, would be filled with thousands of worshipers during the holy month of Ramadan, but now it is mostly empty, except for stacks of coffins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: A Lifetime of Running With Ahmaud Arbery Ends With a Text: ‘We Lost Maud’
description: Ahmaud Arbery and Akeem Baker were best friends who treated each other as brothers. With one now gone, the other struggles to move on.
content: ATLANTA — Long after Akeem Baker escaped the orbit of small-town Georgia, he would continue to rely on his best friend, Ahmaud Arbery. He had relied on him almost from the beginning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Myles E. Johnson
title: Little Richard’s Queer Triumph
description: The legend himself sometimes sought to distance himself from the L.G.B.T.Q. community. But his queerness is what made him a dynamic performer.
content: It was during a 1966 concert in Paris when Little Richard, drenched in sweat, told a mostly white audience, “I’m ready, ready, ready teddy, I’m ready, ready, ready teddy!” He took off his soaked shirt and the men and women pleaded for it as he swung it over his head like a helicopter, carefully considering who he would bless with his dripping D.N.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Levitan, Nicholas Caputo, Roberto Cosentini and Jorge Cabrera
title: We Treated Older Coronavirus Patients. Here’s How to Save More of Them.
description: Requiring pulse oximetry in nursing homes would be a big step.
content: We are emergency and I.C.U. doctors who have worked in three hothouses of the Covid-19 pandemic: Northern Italy, New York City and Miami. Treating scores of critically ill patients, we all observed similar patterns: Many of the patients we saw in our emergency rooms had advanced cases of Covid-19 pneumonia when they arrived — and many of those critically ill patients came from nursing homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: Ahmaud Arbery and the America That Doesn’t Exist
description: Black Americans need more than a trial and a verdict.
content: WHEATON, Ill. — Football does not prepare its athletes for a life of fitness. Its drills and exercises are meant to harden the body for collisions. After our playing days are over, we must find new ways to keep our bodies in shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Goldberger
title: Jaquelin Taylor Robertson, Architect and Passionate Urbanist, Dies at 88
description: Devoted to classical architecture, he was equally committed to design that benefits city life and helped establish a New York agency to promote it.
content: Jaquelin Taylor Robertson, an architect who grew up on a grand classical estate in Virginia before becoming one of New York’s most prominent and impassioned advocates of urban design, died on Saturday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: ‘The Whole Place Is Sick Now’: 72 Deaths at a Home for U.S. Veterans
description: Half of New Jersey’s Covid-19 fatalities are linked to nursing homes. Nowhere has the devastation been starker than at one built for members of the military.
content: The coronavirus has preyed on residents of nursing homes in New Jersey with lethal force, claiming more than 4,850 lives. Deaths at long-term care facilities now account for half of the state’s Covid-19 fatalities, well over the national rate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: N.Y.C. Reports 38 Cases of Virus-Related Syndrome in Children
description: The inflammatory syndrome, which health officials said resembles toxic shock, has killed three children in the state, and Mayor Bill de Blasio urged parents to watch for symptoms.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio said Sunday that 38 New York City children have been inflicted with a serious new inflammatory syndrome that city health officials say appears to be linked to an immune response to Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Europe’s Battle-Hardened Nations Show Resilience in Virus Fight
description: Countries such as Croatia and Greece, which took early measures to stop the outbreak, have generally been aided by cooperation from citizens galvanized by tough recent experiences of war or financial disaster.
content: BRUSSELS — As the coronavirus has hopscotched the world, a paradox has emerged: Rich nations are not necessarily better at fighting the crisis than poorer ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: China Flare-up, Taiwan, Bangkok Pet Salons: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Reid J. Epstein
title: A Fight Over the Future of the Mail Breaks Down Along Familiar Lines
description: With the coronavirus pandemic threatening the Postal Service’s financial viability, a rescue for America’s favorite agency has become a political battle.
content: Its roots stretch back almost 250 years to the Second Continental Congress. Americans consistently rate it their favorite federal agency, and with a work force of more than half a million scattered across the country, it employs more people than any government entity outside the military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and John Eligon
title: In Ahmaud Arbery’s Hometown, Pain, Anger and Pride in a Shared Racial History
description: Brunswick, Ga., gained national attention during the Civil Rights era for the way black and white leaders had worked together to integrate peacefully.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — A 26-year-old black man stood on the steps of the old brick courthouse on Friday and decried the shooting death of another black man who would have turned 26 that day had he lived to see it. “That could have easily been me,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shreeya Sinha
title: Pregnant in a Pandemic? These 5 Mothers of Newborns Have Advice
description: Try to laugh, trust your own judgment and concentrate on your baby.
content: Before the coronavirus, expectant mothers relied on support from family and friends to help them recover from painful deliveries and adapt to unpredictable life with a newborn. Now many parents have to go it alone and make gut-wrenching decisions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: ‘Gate Was Zero,’ but Dana White Says U.F.C. 249 Was a Success
description: The organization’s president voiced optimism even after a bout on Saturday was canceled because a fighter tested positive for the virus.
content: At a news conference after a pay-per-view card, Dana White, the Ultimate Fighting Championship president, usually strolls to the dais clutching a sheet of paper and reads out the event’s attendance and ticket revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Death of James Jordan: What We Know
description: Two men are serving life sentences in prison for the death of Michael Jordan’s father, James, in 1993. One has maintained his innocence, and the other is now under review for parole.
content: In 1993, Michael Jordan was on top of the basketball world. He had won three straight N.B.A. championships with the Chicago Bulls and an Olympic gold medal with the heralded Dream Team. There seemed to be no ceiling to his fame. And with him every step of the way was the person he considered his closest confidant, his father, James Jordan.
source.name: The New York Times
